questions.title: Part 1: Learning better/faster ways of doing the same task
questions.text: The first questionnaire is about learning better ways of completing tasks that you already do. The next questionnaire will be about learning new functionality.

When there are multiple ways of completing the same task, how do users learn the 'better/expert' ways?


For example, using the keyboard shortcut to save a document instead of selecting 'save' from the menu is typically a faster way of accomplishing the same task.


We are interested in learning what tools/methods users employ to learn these 'better/expert' techniques.

questions.instructions: On a scale of 1 to 5, how interested are you in learning shortcuts or better/faster ways of accomplishing tasks that you already know how to do?
When you consider applications that you frequently use, how many times a month (on average) do you learn a better way of accomplishing the same task?
How many times a month (on average) do you use the following methods to learn better/faster ways of using an application

q_text.text: System suggestion other than tip of the day
Internet search (eg: How to do X faster)
Performed it by mistake when trying to do something else
Read about it in an article

questions.instructions: Are there any other methods you use to learn better/faster ways of using an application, which are not listed above? (Optional)
Think of a time when you learned a better way of doing a task.  Please state the application, what method you used to learn this new information, and give a brief description of what you learned.
Do you have any other comments? (Optional)
